questions.text: A 7 year old child presents with a unilateral nasal obstruction and a smooth, greyish mass noted on nasal examination. The mass extends posteriorly and is visible in the nasopharynx. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man presents to the ENT clinic with a complaint of persistent nasal obstruction and intermittent epistaxis (nosebleeds) for the past three months. He also reports a sensation of pressure in his right nasal cavity. The patient has a history of smoking and does not have any known allergies. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 57-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a slowly enlarging, thickened area on his nose that has developed over the past several years. He has a history of rosacea and has noticed increased facial flushing over the past few years. There are no associated symptoms of pain or itching. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is suspected in a 45-year-old male who presents with chronic sinusitis, hemoptysis, and hematuria. A chest X-ray shows multiple cavitating nodules. Which of the following antibodies is most commonly associated with GPA?

A 35-year-old male has chronic nasal obstruction, anosmia, and thick nasal crusting with foul-smelling discharge for the past several years. On examination, the following is found.. Culture reveals Klebsiella ozaenae. All of the following options are potential treatment modalities to manage the condition except:

A 55-year-old woman has a history of progressive nasal congestion, loss of smell, and chronic nasal crusting. Her husband noted a foul smell from her. She has noticed worsening nasal obstruction despite the absence of nasal secretions. On examination, there is evidence of nasal cavity widening with significant crusting and atrophy of the nasal mucosa. Nasal endoscopy shows extensive widespread thinning of the mucosa and bones on turbinates. Which of the following is NOT typically associated with the etiology of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Two types of atrophic rhinitis

Primary

Exact cause is not known

Secondary

Secondary to infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma, radiotherapy to nose, or excessive surgical removal of turbinates or severely deviated septum.

Theories of primary atrophic rhinitis

Hereditary

Disease involvement in more than one member of the same family.

Endocrine (Option C)

Disease usually starts at puberty, involves females more than males, and subsides after menopause.

Racial

White and yellow races > natives of equatorial Africa.

Nutritional deficiency

Vitamin A, D, or iron

Infective

  • Various organisms have been cultured from cases of atrophic rhinitis.
  • Klebsiella ozaenae is the most common organism. (Option A)

Autoimmune (Option D)

Destructive process to the antigens released from the nasal mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT usually a cause of unilateral nasal polyps?
Which of the following conditions is least likely to be misdiagnosed as nasal polyps on clinical examination?

A 35-year-old male patient presents with persistent nasal congestion, difficulty breathing, and headaches. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed. What is the most appropriate initial step in managing his condition?

A 35-year-old patient presents with nasal congestion, difficulty breathing, and frequent headaches. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals multiple sessile masses resembling a bunch of grapes, which are insensitive to touch and do not bleed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman with a history of bronchial asthma and aspirin intolerance presents with worsening nasal congestion, sinus infections, and diminished sense of smell. Nasal polyps are observed on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Rhinosinusitis

 
  • Seen in both allergic and nonallergic origins of chronic rhinosinusitis.
  • Nonallergic Rhinitis with Eosinophilia Syndrome (NARES) is a specific type of chronic rhinitis linked with polyps.

Asthma

 
  • 7% of asthma patients may develop nasal polyps.
  • Including both atopic and nonatopic asthma.

Aspirin Intolerance

 
  • 36% of patients with aspirin intolerance may have nasal polyps.
  • Samter’s Triad: Combination of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance. (Option B)

Cystic Fibrosis (Option A ruled out)

 
  • 20% of patients with cystic fibrosis develop nasal polyps.
  • Caused by abnormal mucus production.

Allergic Fungal Sinusitis

Almost all cases present with nasal polyps.

Kartagener Syndrome (Option D ruled out)

Includes bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliary dyskinesia.

Young Syndrome

 
  • Characterized by sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.

Churg-Strauss Syndrome (Option C ruled out)
  • Features asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis, and granuloma.

Nasal Mastocytosis

 
  • Chronic rhinitis with mast cell infiltration in the nasal mucosa.
  • Few eosinophils are present; allergy skin tests and IgE levels are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ethmoidal polyps?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethmoidal polyps often arise from the middle meatus.

options.label: B
options.text: Allergic nasal polyps commonly originate from the septum.

options.label: C
options.text: Ethmoidal polyps can grow anteriorly and may present at the nares.

options.label: D
options.text: A common site for ethmoidal polyp is the uncinate process.

questions.correct_answer: B. Allergic nasal polyps commonly originate from the septum.
questions.explanation:
Antrochoanal polyp

Ethmoidal polyp

Age

Common in children

Common in adult

Number

Solitary

Multiple

Laterality

Unilateral

Bilateral

Origin

Maxillary sinus near the ostium

Ethmoidal sinuses, middle turbinate and middle meatus

Growth

Grows backwards to the choana; may hang down behind the soft palate

Mostly grow anteriorly and may present at the nares

Size and shape
  • Trilobed (dumb-bell) with antral, nasal and choanal parts.
  • Choanal parts may protrude through the choana & fill the nasopharynx obstructing both sides

Usually small and grape-like masses

Recurrence

Uncommon if removed completely

Common

Treatment

The treatment is only surgical

About 50% of patients respond to steroid therapy

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a history of nasal obstruction predominantly on the right side, mouth breathing, and occasional snoring for the past year. He also has intermittent right-sided nasal discharge and postnasal drip. There is no history of allergies or asthma. A smooth, grayish mass is seen in the right nasal cavity extending into the nasopharynx on rhinoscopic examination. Which among the following is the most appropriate next step in managing his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a non-contrast CT scan and plan for FESS

options.label: C
options.text: Plain X-ray and perform a biopsy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Perform a non-contrast CT scan and plan for FESS

questions.text: A 9 y/o child presents with a unilateral nasal obstruction, hyponasality, and a mucoid nasal discharge. Anterior rhinoscopy shows a smooth, greyish mass, but the polyp is not fully visible. What is the most likely finding on posterior rhinoscopy?

options.label: A
options.text: A pink and congested mass in the anterior nasal cavity

options.label: B
options.text: A globular mass behind the soft palate in the nasopharynx

options.label: C
options.text: A firm, non-movable mass in the maxillary antrum

options.label: D
options.text: A midline pit with protruding hair in the nasal dorsum

questions.correct_answer: B. A globular mass behind the soft palate in the nasopharynx
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Details

Unilateral Nasal Obstruction

Caused by the polyp's growth into the choana, leading to one-sided nasal blockage.

Bilateral Nasal Obstruction

Occurs if the polyp is large enough to obstruct both choanae by protruding into the nasopharynx.

Hyponasality (Rhinolalia clausa)

Change in voice quality to a "thick" or "dull" sound due to nasal resonance obstruction.

Nasal Discharge

Mucoid discharge, unilateral or bilateral depending on the polyp's size and location.

Examination

Findings

Anterior Rhinoscopy
  • May miss the polyp if posterior; visible as a smooth, greyish mass with nasal discharge.
  • Can be soft and movable, or protrude pink and congested from the nostril.

Posterior Rhinoscopy
  • Reveals a globular mass in the nasopharynx, behind the soft palate.
  • Anterior nasal cavity, nasal dorsum, maxillary antrum are not visible on posterior rhinoscopy

Nasal Endoscopy

Provides detailed view of the polyp’s origin in the maxillary antrum, its three parts, and its extent within the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

questions.text: Match the stages of rhinoscleroma with its characteristics features: Stages of rhinoscleroma Characteristic features 1. Atrophic stage a. Stenosis of nares and nasopharynx. 2. Granulomatous stage b. Painless and non-ulcerative nodules. 3. Cicatricial stage c. Foul smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting. d. Black membrane in the nasal mucosa.
questions.explanation:
Stages of rhinoscleroma

Characteristic features

1. Atrophic stage

c. Foul smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

2. Granulomatous stage

b. Painless and non-ulcerative nodules.

3. Cicatricial stage

a. Stenosis of nares and nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 5 y/o child presents with a midline pit on the nasal dorsum, with hair protruding from the opening. Imaging reveals a sinus tract leading to a cyst under the nasal bone. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical excision of the cyst and sinus tract

options.label: D
options.text: Corticosteroid injection to reduce the cyst

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical excision of the cyst and sinus tract
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Simple Dermoids

Midline swellings under the skin, in front of nasal bones, no external opening.

Dermoids with a Sinus

Common in infants/children; midline sinus on nasal dorsum, often with hair protruding from the opening.

Nasal Dermoids

Present with widening of the upper nasal septum, splaying of nasal bones, hypertelorism; may have a midline pit with protruding hair.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presents with a firm swelling on the bridge of the nose. Imaging reveals that the mass is encapsulated and has no connection to the brain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Presentation Type

Description

Extranasal (60%)

Firm, subcutaneous swellings. Common locations: bridge of the nose, side of the nose, near the inner canthus (corner of the eye).

Intranasal (30%)

Located entirely within the nasal cavity.

Combined (10%)

Have both intranasal and extranasal components.

questions.text: A 2 month old infant presents with a pulsatile swelling at the root of the nose that changes size when the infant coughs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Location

Description

Nasofrontal

At the root of the nose

Nasoethmoid

Side of the nose

Naso-orbital

Anteromedial aspect of the orbit (eye socket)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a soft, compressible mass at the root of the nose. The mass increases in size when the baby cries and shows a positive Furstenberg test. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Meningocele

Definition

Herniation of the meninges with the CSF through a congenital defect in the skull base.

Etiology

Caused by incomplete fusion of the bones in the roof of the nose (frontal bone, cribriform plate of the ethmoid, or sphenoid), leading to herniation of meninges.

Types

The Suwanwela and Suwanwela classification is used to categorize different types of meningo-encephaloceles based on their location and anatomical features.

  • Occipital (most common)
  • Cranial Vault
  • Fronto-Ethmoidal (Sincipital)
  • Basal
  • Posterior Fossa

Clinical Features
  • Soft, cystic swelling
  • Positive compressibility, reducibility, transillumination and cough impulse.
  • Furstenberg test - positive(the size of a nasal or cranial mass increases upon applying pressure to the internal jugular veins or by valsalva)

Diagnosis
  • CT and MRI imaging are critical;
  • Biopsy is contraindicated.

Treatment

Surgical excision and skull base reconstruction.

questions.text: A 2-day-old full-term male infant is brought to the emergency room with difficulty breathing, especially when feeding, and cyanosis. The cyanosis improves when the infant cries but worsens when feeding. The baby is in respiratory distress. What is the best initial emergency management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Inserting a wide bore feeding nipple into the mouth of the infant

questions.correct_answer: A. Inserting a wide bore feeding nipple into the mouth of the infant
questions.explanation:
Choanal Atresia

Incidence

1 in 7000 live births.

Etiology

Persistence of nasobuccal membrane of Hochstetter. (Option C)

Types
  • Unilateral (more common)
  • Bilateral
  • Complete
  • Incomplete
  • Bony (30%)
  • Membranous
  • Mixed (70%)

Clinical Features

Bilateral choanal atresia (presents during neonatal period):

  • Acute respiratory distress (as neonates are obligate nasal breathers)
  • Cyclical cyanosis relieved by crying.
  • Cyanosis during feeding.

Unilateral choanal atresia (presents later in life):

  • Failure to pass nasogastric tube on that side

Associated Syndrome

CHARGE syndrome: (due to mutations in the CHD7 gene on chromosome 8)

  • Coloboma
  • Heart defects
  • Atresia choanae
  • Retardation of growth
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear abnormalities

These abnormalities must be excluded in a child with choanal atresia and therefore the minimum investigations in addition to the nasal CT scan are cardiac echo, renal ultrasound scan, and an ophthalmology and audiology review.

Diagnosis

Clinical:

  • Misting test with a metal spatula below nasal aperture.
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Definitive investigations:

  • CT scan ( after suction and nasal decongestants)
  • Nasal endoscopy

Management

Immediate:

  • Oral airway placement.
  • A wide bore feeding nipple is inserted into the mouth of the infant - Mc Govern’s technique. (Option A)

Definitive: Surgery (at 1.5 years of age)

  • Endoscopic transnasal approach (most common).
  • Transpalatal approach used in complex cases.

Post op complication and management.
  • Granulation tissue formation
  • Managed with: KTP laser, Mitomycin C.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the clinic with respiratory distress, which worsens during feeding and improves with crying. The baby shows difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube through one nasal passage, and a CT scan reveals a mixed bony and membranous obstruction in the posterior nasal cavity. This condition is due to the persistence of which membrane during development?
questions.explanation:
Choanal Atresia

Incidence

1 in 7000 live births.

Etiology

Persistence of nasobuccal membrane of Hochstetter. (Option C)

Types
  • Unilateral (more common)
  • Bilateral
  • Complete
  • Incomplete
  • Bony > Membranous
  • Mixed (70%)

Clinical Features

Bilateral choanal atresia (presents during neonatal period):

  • Acute respiratory distress (as neonates are obligate nasal breathers)
  • Cyclical cyanosis relieved by crying.
  • Cyanosis during feeding.

Unilateral choanal atresia (presents later in life):

  • Failure to pass nasogastric tube on that side

Associated Syndrome

CHARGE syndrome: (due to mutations in the CHD7 gene on chromosome 8)

  • Coloboma
  • Heart defects
  • Atresia choanae
  • Retardation of growth
  • Genital anomalies
  • Ear abnormalities

These abnormalities must be excluded in a child with choanal atresia and therefore the minimum investigations in addition to the nasal CT scan are cardiac echo, renal ultrasound scan, and an ophthalmology and audiology review.

Diagnosis

Clinical:

  • Misting test with a metal spatula below nasal aperture.
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Definitive investigations:

  • CT scan ( after suction and nasal decongestants)
  • Nasal endoscopy

Management

Immediate:

  • Oral airway placement.
  • A wide bore feeding nipple is inserted into the mouth of the infant - Mc Govern’s technique.

Definitive: Surgery (at 1.5 years of age)

  • Endoscopic transnasal approach (most common).
  • Transpalatal approach used in complex cases.

Post-op complication and management.
  • Granulation tissue formation and re-stenosis
  • Managed with: KTP laser, Mitomycin C.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of nasal obstruction, crusting, and facial pain that have been worsening over the past few months. She reports persistent nasal congestion and frequent nosebleeds. On physical examination, there is purplish discoloration of the nasal skin and a nasal endoscopy reveals erythematous mucosa covered with pale granulomas, as shown in the image. A biopsy of the nasal lesion reveals non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.explanation:
Granulomatous Conditions of the Nose: Sarcoidosis
  • Immune-mediated chronic granulomatous disease.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement is up to 9%.

Epidemiology

More frequent in women

Peak age: 30-40 years.

Clinical features
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Crusting
  • Purplish discoloration - lupus pernio (specific)
  • Nasal bleeding
  • Facial pain.
  • Nasal mucosa - characteristic ‘strawberry’ appearance of inflamed erythematous mucosa covered with pale granulomas.
  • Anterior septal perforation- usually only involves cartilagenous part.

Investigations
  • Non-specific: Elevated serum ACE, hypercalcemia.
  • Kveim test (outdated)
  • Imaging: CXR (bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy), CT for sinus/nasal involvement.
  • Biopsy: Non-caseating granulomas. (Confirmatory)

Staging

Krespi staging of sinonasal sarcoidosis

  • Stage I: Mild, reversible (nose only).
  • Stage II: Moderate, reversible (nose + limited sinuses).
  • Stage III: Severe, irreversible sinonasal disease.

Management
  • Systemic steroids (Option C) (mainstay), methotrexate (steroid-sparing).
  • Topical: Nasal steroids, douching, lubricants.

Prognosis

Two-thirds remit spontaneously.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, non-healing lesion on his nasal tip, accompanied by intermittent nasal obstruction. Over the past several months, the lesion has progressively worsened. On examination, the following lesion is seen as shown in the image. A biopsy of the lesion reveals caseating granulomas. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Granulomatous Infection of the Nose: Tuberculosis

Causative organism

Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Epidemiology

Usually secondary to pulmonary TB.

Primary nasal TB accounts for only one-third of cases.

Types

Ulcerative form:

  • Affects the anterior cartilaginous part of the nasal septum and the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, causing perforation.

Nodular form: Lupus vulgaris

  • Low-grade cutaneous TB infection in the nasal vestibule
  • Present as pale reddish nodules on the dorsum or tip of the nose, which does not blanch on pressure, known as Apple jelly nodules.

Diagnosis
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Caseating epithelioid granulomas.
  • Acid-fast bacilli staining (may be negative)
  • Cultures (may be negative)
  • Skin testing (e.g., tuberculin skin test)
  • Serum testing (e.g., QuantiFERON)

Management

Both types of nasal TB are treated with combination antituberculous chemotherapy (ATT).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, recurrent nasal bleeding, and a mass protruding from his nasal cavity. On examination, a polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface is noted. It bleeds easily on touch. A biopsy is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Complete excision of the mass

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of nasal obstruction, recurrent nasal bleeding, and mass protruding from his nasal cavity. He reports frequent swimming in freshwater ponds. Which of the following findings on clinical examination is most characteristic of rhinosporidiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface

options.label: B
options.text: Soft, dark red, pedunculated or sessile mass

options.label: D
options.text: Firm, rounded, yellowish mass with blood vessels on the surface

questions.correct_answer: A. Polypoidal, pink-colored mass with white dots on the surface

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a history of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds, and crusting. On examination, she has a nasal deformity with a firm mass in the nasal cavity. A biopsy of the mass shows Mikulicz cells and is positive for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis . What is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

questions.correct_answer: A. Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a rural area has nasal obstruction, crusting, and a history of progressive nasal swelling over the past several months. On examination, nodular masses in the nasal cavity are noted. A biopsy is done and shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of the condition in this patient?
